snippet: Ahmad Chalabi, once championed by the Bush administration as a possible leader for Iraq and then pushed aside for faulty depictions of weapons of mass destruction, has re-emerged in talks among the country’s political parties as a contender for...
abstract: Ahmad Chalabi, once championed by Bush administration as a possible leader for Iraq and then pushed aside for faulty depictions of weapons of mass destruction, has re-emerged in talks among country’s political parties as a contender for prime minister; his consideration is measure of his skills as a political operator, as well as desperate state of the effort to forge new Iraqi government amid severe sectarian strains.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Alissa J. Rubin, Duraid Adnan, Suadad al-Salhy and Marwa Salman from Baghdad, and Michael R. Gordon from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Ahmad Chalabi, once championed by the Bush administration as a possible leader for Iraq and then pushed aside for faulty depictions of weapons of mass destruction, has re-emerged in talks among the country’s political parties as a contender for prime minister.

headline.main: For Iraq, Potential Leader With a Tarnished Past
headline.print_headline: For Iraq, Potential Leader With a Tarnished Past
